reviewText:
Rogue of the Range, 1936 film

A man shoots open a locked metal box and takes out three bags. He robbed a stage coach shipment before another gang could! The four riders chase this man, but he hides from them; then he hides the three bags. A wagon driven by a woman runs along a road. Her grandfather is in the back of the wagon, resting peacefully. The people are told about this lone robber, who could he be? A doctor is called to see the man in the wagon. A woman leads the men in a song in the tavern. Dan Doran needs a new shoe for his horse. Does it match the shoe found by the robbery? Yes, the Sheriff arrests Dan. Will the law go easy on him if he turns over the loot? One man hears where the loot was hidden. Stella tells Dan he shouldnt have admitted it.

Dan asks Stella to take care of that Gospel Girl. When the Sheriff goes to look for the loot it is gone! Dan goes to prison. A peddler goes to the Gold Nugget Cafe for food. Dan has plans to escape from prison (with inside help). The alarm sounds, Dan and his friend escape from prison, and use the two horses left outside. Now he is invited to join the gang. The newspapers tell of the escape of Dan Doran and Jim Mitchell, there is a reward of $1,000. Dan meets Stella, and shows her his Federal Secret Service badge. Dan explains the secret, he cant trust anyone else. There is a complication to the meeting! Dan tells Sheriff Tom that someone has inside information on the gold shipments. The robbery goes as planned but the bags have steel washers not gold!

The Express company prepared for a probable robbery. Dan reads the note about Branscombs upcoming marriage; Tom asks how it can be prevented. Branscomb sees the together! Branscomb tells the gang leader about this. The gang is told about the death of a spy. Dan uses a trick to escape from the gang, they ride after him but he eludes them. The gang will pack up and disappear, but the Sheriff has another plan. The next day Branscomb travels to that town to get married; Stella goes along. Stella drives off and leaves Branscomb behind! Branscomb finds a note telling him where to find a horse. Branscomb goes to the gangs hideout to leave a note, Doran follow him to get that note. There is a fight in that cabin, Dan wins. He returns to Stella and surprises her.

One regular theme in these Westerns is how a rich and important person in town is really crooked; and how a seemingly guilty person is really innocent. Was this a popular idea from the Great Depression where the failures of the Establishment caused the Great Depression? The recurrent use of this idea didn't hurt sales of movie tickets. There was no excessive use of actors, scenes may have been edited to limit the running time.

Supreme Pictures present "ROGUE ON THE RANGE" (1936) (digitally remastered), long running Johnny Mack Brown series turned out in the early '40s...the story line has Johnny Mack Brown giving us a better than average western plot at what he does best - fighting, riding and roping the heavies leaving us with pure enjoyment ... relive those thrilling days when Johnny Mack Brown took us down the dusty trails with hard riding and straight shooting hitting the bull's eye with excitement every time ... the Johnny Mack Brown series of B-Westerns were a staple of Saturday matinees in the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s ... will the final showdown live up to all we expect from the Johnny Mack Brown Supreme feature film series...producer A.W. Hackel delivers another over the top film and gives the B-Western fans all the excitement and drama we long for.

Under S. Roy Luby (Director), A.W. Hackel (Producer), Earle Snell (Screenwriter), Jack Greenhalgh (Cinematographer), S.Roy Luby (Editor) - - - - the cast includes Johnny Mack Brown (Dan Doran), Lois January (Stella Lamb), Alden 'Stephen' Chase (Lige Branscomb (as Alden Chase), Phyllis Hume (Tess), George Ball (Jim Mitchell), Jack Rockwell (Henchman Sloan), Horace Murphy (Sheriff Tom), Frank Ball (John (express agent), Oscar Gahan (Stage guard) - - - - released on April 25, 1936, story line has our hero Johnny Mack Brown and Sheriff Horace Murphy with a plan to catch the culprits that have been robbing the local stagecoaches ... Johnny Mack is sent off to prison and escapes to get in with the gang and discover the leader ... but wait, Alden Stephen Chase has found out that Johnny Mack is really a G-Man ... don't touch that dial until the very last chapter - - - - meanwhile back to another great Johnny Mack B-Western provided by Supreme Pictures during their heyday of the early '30s.

SPECIAL FEATURES:

BIOS:

1. Johnny Mack Brown

Birth Date: 9/01/1904 - Dothan, Alabama

Died: 11/14/1974 - Woodland Hills, California (cardiac condition)

2.  Lois January

Date of Birth:  5 October 1912 - McAllen, Texas

Date of Death:  7 August 2006 - Los Angeles, California

3.  Alden 'Stephen' Chase

Date of Birth:  11 April 1902 - Huntington, Long Island, New York

Date of Death:  1 April 1982 - Santa Monica, California

4. S. Roy Luby (Director)

Birth Date: 8/08/1904 - New York, New York

Died: 8/19/1976 - Los Angeles, California

5. A.W. Hackel (Producer)

Birth Date: 12/18.1882 - Austria

Died: 10/22/1959 - Los Angeles, California

If you crave action, drama and plenty of adventure check out other western double features by Johnny Mack Brown:

JOHNNY MACK BROWN WESTERN DOUBLE FEATURES:

1. Raiders of San Joaquin/Law of the Range (VCI #7226)

2. Pony Post/Ragtime Cowboy Joe (VCI #7238)

3. Brand A Coward/Rogue of the Range (VCI #7244)

4. Guns in the Dark/Partner of the Trail (VCI #7260)

5. Bar Z Bad Men/Between Men (VCI #7282)

Ask Amazon. Com to carry the above five titles as they are not available on Amazon as of yet...you can order and pick up your copy now from VCI Entertainment...if you enjoyed "Rogue of the Range" (1936), why not pick up other copies of Johnny Mack Brown Double Features.

Bobby J. Copeland's book on "Johnny Mack Brown: Up Close & Personal" is chuck full of answers to all the questions his fans had from early on...when you went to see him on the big screen, you got exactly what the marquee said...plenty of thrills, adventure and loaded with action...Johnny Mack was a natural for the western, his riding abilities and fight scenes were of the the same caliber as Buck Jones and Bob Steele...Johnny Mack sets the saddle better than Duke Wayne...seems Johnny got better with the more films he made and the scripts were always top notch...he was one of the best-liked people in films, what you saw on the screen is what he really was, a great human being...pickup your copy from Amazon or Empire Publishing both have this in stock.

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc), Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") and Trevor Scott (Down Under Com) as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '20s, '30s & '40s and B-Westerns ... order your copy now from Amazon where there are plenty of copies available on VHS, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure --- if you enjoyed this title, why not check out VCI Entertainment where they are experts in releasing B-Westerns and Serials --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 58 min on DVD/VHS ~ ATZ 60046 ~ (2/19/2007)
